comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content:
There is something odd about this photo,   the large buildings towards the left seem curiously oversized as though they have been badly edited into the photo.   Its the Zarra Street Power station which was last used in about 1971 and demolished a few years later.

The photo is taken from in front of the lighthouse on Nobby's.

I can't make out the large church which should be conspicuous on top of the hill in the middle of the photo.   

I can't spot the distinctive stockton car ferries which were used in the 60's,  for how long before, I don't know.

The fort is just out of shot to the left.

comment.author: 89648668@N05
comment._content: Here's a similar view from the State Library of NSW - this collection is dated c. 1900-1910. acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=413798 The State Records one is later - telegraph poles, more buildings etc... The Zaara St Power Station was built in the early1920s, so after that...

comment.author: 78690340@N07
comment._content:
1930-35

Zaara St power station operational in 1920

no State Dockyard on the Dyke End, so before 1938
no large wheat silos at Carrington, so before about 1936
no Nobbys Beach pavilion (designed 1934, built 1935?)
 can't see the clock tower on City Hall (c1929) but it may be lost in the smoke, as the St Andrews church spire is not visible either

a lot of small buildings at Horseshoe Beach which may be the Nobbys shanty town (1930? - 1937 - Depression) which was replaced by the Camp Shortland army base.

comment._content:

I don't know Newcastle well, and was going to guess c.1925.  Maybe you can offer something on this photo / pano -

comment.author: 78690340@N07
78690340@N07
comment._content: panorama of Newcastle Harbour 1928 from the Cathedral (Hunter photo bank) "Nobby's, Newcastle from Fort Scratchley" [096 000073]" in Hunter Photobank is a view towards Nobbys from Fort Scratchley in January, 1938 - the new Nobbys Beach pavilion in foreground, shanty town at Horseshoe Beach on left (haven't worked out how to get a link yet)

comment.author: 89711815@N07
comment._content: I  along with with several of the photo researchers at Fort Scratchley had a look at this photo and compared it with photos that are at Fort Scratchley  we estimate the crica as between 1927- 1934. I. Nobby's surf club was not completed until 1934, on the small breakwall is a car estimate to be a 1927 Chev. 2) What looks like to be the shanty town of Nobbys at Horseshoe beach. that sprung up during the great depression.

comment.author: 78690340@N07
comment._content:
Nobbys camp - 1930s ( from caption probably c1937-38)  - the Zaara St Power station is visible in the background.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/uon/6518446395/]

another Hunter Photobank image showing the surf shed (a small weatherboard building) on Nobbys Beach before the present pavilion was built - :
"Mayor Cornish opening new surf shed at Nobbys Beach"   [163 001905] - opened 1/12/1923

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
There is some great detective work here! I'm trying to put it together to get our closest date range and so far have:
1920-1935 
( Zaara St power station - top left - was operating by 1920 and Nobbys beach pavilion opened in 1935 - can anyone verify these dates?)
